Title: üñº An official from Komi, accused of corruption, asks to go to wa...
Description: An official from Komi, accused of corruption, asks to go to war with UkraineFormer first deputy head of the administration of the city of Pechora in the Komi Republic, Andrei Kanishchev, who is under investigation on charges of corruption, signed a contract with the Russian Ministry of Defense and expressed his intention to go to the zone of a special military operation in Ukraine. A corresponding petition to suspend the criminal case was received by the Pechora City Court, but at the moment it has not yet been considered, local media writes.  Kanishchev is accused of receiving a bribe on an especially large scale and exceeding official authority. According to investigators, he, together with the former mayor of Pechora Valery Serov, received a bribe in the amount of four million rubles from a commercial company for assistance in concluding a government contract to carry out work to improve the city. At the time of the initiation of this criminal case, Kanishchev was already in custody on another charge. In February 2024, he was sentenced to 10 years in prison for intentionally causing grievous bodily harm, negligently resulting in the death of the victim. In August 2022, Kanishchev hit sound engineer Viktor Fateev during a fire show on the main stage of Pechora, which led to his death. The case of Kanishchev is notsingle. Since the beginning of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, 108 Russian officials and deputies have declared their desire to go to the front. Of these, 70 did this voluntarily, and 18, who were under criminal prosecution, chose to avoid it by signing contracts with the Ministry of Defense. The remaining 20 people subsequently abandoned their intentions.In March 2023, the mayor of Vorkuta, Yaroslav Shaposhnikov, announced that he would go to war in Ukraine. But he did this only after 118 days, citing the fact that the then acting head of Komi, Vladimir Uyba, asked him to stay.In May 2023, the acting Minister of Health of Komi, Igor Diaghilev, voluntarily went to the front, where he worked as a traumatologist in a military hospital. A year and a half later, in October 2024, after his return, he was appointed deputy prime minister of the government of the republic.The former first deputy head of the administration of Syktyvkar, Alexander Mozhegov, also found himself in the combat zone. The reasons for his participation in the war were not officially reported.Another official from Komi, ex-head of the Kortkeros district Alexander Arteev, came to the front from a penal colony. In 2023, he was sentenced to 13 years in prison for accepting bribes. In July 2024, his death became known.

Description: Political prisoners will not be included in the May amnestyDeputies of the Communist Party faction led by Gennady Zyuganov submitted to the State Duma a draft resolution on an amnesty dedicated to the 80th anniversary of Victory in the Great Patriotic War, writes TASS. The document provides for the release from punishment of persons convicted for the first time for intentional crimes of minor and moderate gravity, as well as certain categories of citizens, including combatants, home front workers, minors, pregnant women and disabled people of groups I and II. However, the draft contains exceptions for a number of articles of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation, to which the amnesty does not apply. Among them are articles 280.3 (repeated discrediting of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation), 207.3 (public dissemination of knowingly false information about the use of the RF Armed Forces) and 205.2 (public calls for terrorist activities or public justification of terrorism). Thus, persons convicted under these articles are not subject to the proposed amnesty, even if they belong to preferential categories such as pregnant women, single parents or pensioners.Previously, some deputies from the United Russia party expressed the opinion that holding an amnesty this year is inappropriate, since the convicts can -atone for their guilt- by signing a contract and going to war with Ukraine.Last A large-scale amnesty in Russia, dedicated to the 70th anniversary of the Victory, was carried out in 2015 and affected about 60 thousand people sentenced to imprisonment and up to 200 thousand suspended sentences. The final decision on the amnesty and its conditions will be made after consideration and discussion of the project in the State Duma.

Title: üñº Russian military spending has exceeded the defense budgets of ...
Description: Russian military spending has exceeded the defense budgets of all European countriesAccording to data from the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS), published on February 12, 2025, Russian military spending in 2024 increased by 42% and reached 13.1 trillion rubles, which is equivalent to $462 billion at purchasing power parity. This amount exceeds the combined defense budgets of all European Union countries and the United Kingdom, which grew by 12% in 2024 to $457 billion, reports the Financial Times. In absolute terms, the largest European defense budgets in 2024 were Germany ($86 billion), the United Kingdom ($81 billion) and France ($64 billion). As a percentage of GDP, the most significant defense expenditures were borne by Estonia (4% of GDP) and Poland (3.25% of GDP), although their absolute costs were less: $1.7 billion and $28 billion, respectively. According to IISS forecasts, in 2025, Russian military spending will increase by 13.7%, reaching 15.6 trillion rubles, which will amount to 7.5% of the country's GDP and almost 40% of the federal budget.

Description: Ukrainian citizens accused of sabotage were sentenced to 23 years in prisonThe First Western District Military Court sentenced Ukrainian citizens Alexander Maystruk and Eduard Usatenko to 23 years in prison on charges of sabotage at facilities energy infrastructure of Russia, reports SOTA vision. According to the case materials, they were part of a sabotage and terrorist group of the Foreign Intelligence Service of Ukraine. The investigation believes that on the eve of Victory Day in 2023, Maystruk and Usatenko blew up one and mined four power transmission towers of the Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant, and also planted explosive devices under seven towers of the Kalinin Nuclear Power Plant. Maystruk and Usatenko, according to investigators, were recruited by an employee of the Foreign Intelligence Service of Ukraine and underwent special training in camps in the Kyiv and Nikolaev regions. Then they illegally crossed the Russian-Belarusian border in the Pskov region, arriving from the territory of Ukraine in transit through Poland and Belarus. The investigation believes that in total Maystruk and Usatenko tried to blow up more than 30 supports of high-voltage power lines at the Leningrad and Kalinin nuclear power plants to stop nuclear reactors and disrupt the normal operation of the nuclear power plant. In addition to Maistruk and Usatenko, the FSB detained two Russian acquaintances who assisted them in providing them with communications equipment and vehicles with fake state registration plates.The court hearings were held behind closed doors. According to the press service of the St. Petersburg courts, Maystruk and Usatenko admitted their guilt. The damage from their actions is estimated at 10.85 million rubles. According to the court's decision, the convicts will spend the first five years in prison and the remaining term in a maximum security colony. In addition, they are required to pay a fine of 10 million rubles. This case was the first in the history of the First Western District Military Court in which the defendants were charged with undergoing training for the purpose of carrying out sabotage and terrorist activities. The indictment included articles on committing a terrorist attack, attempted terrorist attack and sabotage, illegal trafficking in weapons and explosives, as well as their smuggling.
